normalised: Here's the normalized version of the Quora post:

unnormalised: **What simple changes can I make in my day-to-day life to reduce waste, particularly in an Indian context?**
normalised: **What simple changes can I make in my day to day life to reduce waste, particularly in an Indian context question mark**

unnormalised: Hey everyone, let’s talk about waste! It's something we all contribute to, but we can also all be part of the solution, right? Especially in India, with our bustling cities like Mumbai and Delhi, waste management is a huge issue.
normalised: Hey everyone, let us talk about waste exclamation mark It is something we all contribute to, but we can also all be part of the solution, right question mark Especially in India, with our bustling cities like Mumbai and Delhi, waste management is a huge issue.

unnormalised: First off, ditch the single-use plastics! Carry your own reusable bag – that jhola your Dadi used to have is perfect! And say no to plastic straws. Remember that scene in "Lage Raho Munna Bhai" where they're cleaning up the beach? Inspiring!
normalised: First off, ditch the single use plastics exclamation mark Carry your own reusable bag – that jhola your Dadi used to have is perfect exclamation mark And say no to plastic straws. Remember that scene in "Lage Raho Munna Bhai" where they are cleaning up the beach question mark Inspiring exclamation mark

unnormalised: Another easy one: segregate your waste. Wet waste for compost, dry waste for recycling. Many municipalities, like the BMC in Mumbai, are making it easier. Composting food scraps can significantly reduce landfill burden. You can even try creating a small vermicomposting setup.
normalised: Another easy one: segregate your waste. Wet waste for compost, dry waste for recycling. Many municipalities, like the B M C in Mumbai, are making it easier. Composting food scraps can significantly reduce landfill burden. You can even try creating a small vermicomposting setup.

unnormalised: Also, look for products with minimal packaging. Support local farmers markets where produce isn’t wrapped in layers of plastic.
normalised: Also, look for products with minimal packaging. Support local farmers markets where produce is not wrapped in layers of plastic.

unnormalised: Think about repairing things instead of immediately throwing them away. That broken chappal might just need a quick fix by the local cobbler.
normalised: Think about repairing things instead of immediately throwing them away. That broken chappal might just need a quick fix by the local cobbler.

unnormalised: Finally, educate yourself and others! Spread awareness in your colony or building. Maybe even start a small waste reduction initiative. Every little bit counts. Even switching to bamboo toothbrushes or using reusable coffee cups can make a difference. Let's aim for a Swachh Bharat, one less plastic bottle at a time!
